It's quite true that the times they are a-changin', and that there are winners and losers in globalization. It is in fact Schumpeter's creative destruction. That is what capitalism does.

1. Mr. Krugman argument leaves out the difference between a good job (manufacturing Caterpillars) and a lousy one (Walmart sales associate).
Because if would bring up what economists call distributive costs - if you are a Walmart employee you may be on food stamps
2. Distributive costs are a sensitive subject for Mr. Krugman, as he omitted them in his 1995 paper that claimed that globalization had only a minimum impact on wages of those exposed to competition from low wage countries. We know now that this was wrong.
3. Mr. Krugman claimed international trade was harmless to those exposed to it until 2008, when in a volte face he stated that the standard model "might" after all be correct.
4. His 1995 paper had disastrous consequences for the American working class in good jobs (e.g. manufacturing) as it was seized upon by politicians of both parties to implement trade agreements.
5. All throughout, Mr. Krugman exhibited contempt for those who lost their jobs, accusing them of " moral outrage" . When he got angry letters from the victims along the lines of, "Well, if you lose your comfortable position as an American professor you can always find another job--as long as you are 12 years old and willing to work for 40 cents an hour." He responded with "Such moral outrage is common among the opponents of globalization "
5. If Mr. Krugman disagrees with Mr. Autors second paper, he should submit a paper to a refereed journal - not misuse his blog for an attack.

The short answer to your first two questions is "Yes." and "Yes."  We built the USA behind a high tariff wall.

It seems to me that it all has to be looked t from a historical perspective. What happened when trade was restricted, when high tariffs were placed on goods from other countries? Did local manufacturing increase, did wages increase?

Also look at what happened when certain companies decided to have their wares made in low cost countries. In the 1990s Walmart became the low cost leader and customers flocked to it to buy cheap shoddy made goods. Small town main streets like Twin Falls Idaho dried up. Other companies like Target did the same to compete, and instead of complaining about lost jobs, the politicians lauded them for making life cheaper. However, their customers were decently paid workers from places like the Rust Belt. Then they discovered those jobs were no longer available for their kids.

Those same people were buying Toyotas and Hondas because they made better cars than GM and Chrysler. Even Ford lost business except for its light trucks. Would higher tariffs kept the auto industry profitable considering the quality was not what the US buyers had come to expect?

Just look at the motor cycle industry. Suddenly you had bikes with starters, quiet, low vibration. fast, and reasonable prices. Harley actually benefited as more Americans rode bikes, and Harley became a boutique bike.

Trade is a two way street you can not defeat the law of supply and demand.
